I am a new mother, and I have battled treatment-resistant depression my whole life. My depression became so much worse after the birth of my baby I had to go into the hospital for a month; my husband had to manage alone with the help of my mom. In the end, it was kratom that allowed me to function enough to live at home be able to care, at least partially, for my beautiful new baby. I did not find that it made me feel "high" - I wouldn't have felt that I could be responsible for a newborn if it had. It simply lifted my depression enough that I could feed her and sing to her and put her to bed - all the things normal mothers take for granted. Also, the fact that kratom actually had an effect on my 20-year treatment-resistant depression helped my doctors by providing evidence they needed to find the right medicine at last. I am now finally, after twenty years, living a normal life with my husband and almost-two-year-old. If I had not discovered kratom when I did, I am positive that I would not be here right now. What really needs to happen is for the DEA to open the door for more research to be done on opiate-based anti-depressants for severe refractory cases, but in the absence of that, the legal status of kratom is incredibly important to maintain for those with depression who find it helpful. In summary: Kratom allowed me to overcome my severe depression enough to function as a new mother, and it also helped me find a medical treatment that actually worked at last after twenty years and twenty-three different laboratory-manufactured medications. Sure it can be abused, but just about anything can be abused if used irresponsibly. Keep alcohol in mind here. I'd be willing to bet that the number of deaths caused by people using kratom (or marijuana, for that matter) is a miniscule, teeny drop in the bucket when compared to alcohol-caused deaths. Please keep this natural, comparatively harmless substance available to those whom it helps.

documents.commentText:
In regard to Docket No. DEA-442W

As I am sure your committee is learning from the numerous comments you have received, Kratom is a natural health supplement which can provide amazing benefits to consumers.  The recent deluge of detailed anecdotal accounts from the people who have been consuming this plant regularly for years constitutes a massive data set for what can now be considered one of the largest-scale clinical trials to date.  

From this information, it has become evident that kratom is used much like St. John's Wort or coffee, and is similar to these products in terms of both its intensity and the potential risks it presents to consumers.  Unlike how it had been characterized by a handful of poorly researched (local) media reports seeking to increase viewership through hysterics and sensationalism, kratom is not a mysterious, fashionable "new recreational drug" being snuck into the country from the orient.  Anyone attempting to use it as such will find themselves sorely disappointed, as one can access numerous products with more mind-altering capabilities in a typical grocery store (alcohol, cough syrup, nitrous oxide in canned whipped cream...), let alone their local pharmacy.  Thus, the allure it presents to drug-seeking youths (beyond the inaccurate media portrayals) is nonexistent.  

Even still, should someone consume kratom in an amount far exceeding a typical serving, we can rest assured knowing that although the consequences may be uncomfortable (possibly resulting in nausea and vomiting), they will not be fatal. Although, there have been a handful of deaths associated with kratom in which the deceased had kratom in their digestive tract upon autopsy examination, in each of these cases the person was shown to have had dangerous/toxic amounts of lethal drugs in their system. To date, there have been zero deaths attributed to kratom consumption. This fact is striking when one considers the estimated 458 deaths from over-the-counter acetaminophen annually. 

Most importantly is how the responsible adults who make the informed decision to consume kratom will be impacted.  The war veterans and grandmothers with fibromyalgia who protested in front of the White House on September 13th represent tens of thousands of Americans who would be criminalized by the scheduling of kratom as a controlled substance.  With its new found attention, scientific research is just now proving what people have known for hundreds of years; kratom has the unique potential to safely and effectively stem opiate addiction.  Considering the crises facing America, it is your jurisdictional responsibility to weigh the potential risks against the benefits.  Criminalizing an innocuous plant possessing widely acknowledged benefits and potentials is simply unjustifiable.  Such a misguided decision would undoubtedly result in a legal battle that would raise serious questions about the motivations of the DEA - diminishing public's faith in the agency and possibly challenging the very constitutionality of the organization itself.

documents.commentText:
Docket No. DEA-442W
Hello:

I work as a registered nurse (RN) in a high-volume hospital emergency department in the western United States. As a front line healthcare worker in this setting I experience, on a nightly basis, the public and personal harm caused by our country's precarious relationship with opioid pain medications. I am writing this comment to express my grave concern with the recent DEA decision to place kratom and its opioid alkaloids on the schedule I substance list.

I first became aware of kratom through the experience of a friend, who consumes the plant to help treat intractable pain caused by advanced neuropathy. I consider it both a personal and professional duty to help my loved ones understand the benefits and risks of any substance they put into their body, the same as I do for the patients I treat. Kratom is a plant with obvious benefits and risks to the public, and a thorough investigation of its pharmacological qualities is quite warranted.

After even a cursory review of existing research and anecdotal evidence, it is clear to me that placing kratom into the schedule I category is premature, highly misguided, and a blatant abuse of DEA authority.

Kratom does demonstrate obvious benefits and risks. Clearly, it is effective in pain management in many people. It also demonstrates immense potential as an alternative to pharmaceutical opioids in those patients who suffer from physical dependency to these medications. Based on anecdotal data, kratom also appears to exhibit the potential for anxiolytic and antidepressant treatment as well.

As with any opioid, the risks of kratom appear to include potential for abuse, mild constipation, and impaired judgment or coordination. There is absolutely zero evidence to support the DEA assertion that kratom contributes to the severe and dangerous side effects of respiratory depression or sudden death. I find it highly irresponsible of the DEA to make such claims.

The pharmacological qualities of kratom warrant further research. Scheduling this plant would effectively halt these efforts, and stands in antithesis of the DEA's aims at harm-reduction and evidence-based policy.

Our country is losing its battle against the chronic use and abuse of oxycodone, hydrocodone, fentanyl, and other opioid pain medications. My heart is broken on a nightly basis observing the direct and collateral damage of this war on patients, families, and communities. Kratom is an immensely promising plant that can assist in this struggleplease do not destroy this tool before we have even began to explore its use.

I implore the DEA to allow further examination of this plant in the medical and scientific communities where its management belongs. Any further abuses of the DEA's scheduling authority will only inflict further direct harm on our country. Prohibition is a failed model and a waste of public resources.

Thank you for considering this comment.

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern,

I oppose putting kratom on the list of schedule 1 controlled substances without any detailed understanding from individuals currently using this supplement or clinical data supporting the criteria that this plant has a high potential for abuse and the potential to create severe psychological and/or physical dependence; quite the opposite.

My wife suffers from a combination of fibromyalgia, high blood pressure, and type-2 diabetes. The doctors prescribed a cocktail of various drugs to treat her symptoms that make her nauseous, give her headaches, insomnia, and negatively affect her taste buds; most food tastes bad and she seldom eats or eats very little which affects her blood sugar.

After a friend told me about kratom, I did some research online. There are multiple articles supporting both the benefits and risks associated with this plant. The articles supporting provided historical evidence of kratoms use in Southeast Asia for treating various maladies and multiple user testimonials. The articles warning of kartoms use came primarily from drug treatment centers and looked more like advertisements to enroll in the various treatment centers without any real evidence that the drug was dangerous or addictive.

With my research behind me, I bought some capsules from an organic supplement store and gave them to my wife as a birthday gift. I was seriously concerned that the medication she was taking was having more harmful side effects than benefit. We agreed that she would stop the meds for two weeks and try this herbal alternative to what the outcome would be. If she didnt feel better, she would go back to the prescriptions. 

We are on our third week, taking 4 pills of Maeng Da kratom per day  2 in the morning and 2 at night. She has been able to fall asleep faster and sleep easier, albeit not as long as I would like. It seems like her appetite has returned but we are still determining that outcome. The blood pressure and sugar spiked for the first 4 days but testing every day is showing a steady decrease. 

Im not suggesting that this is some super plant that will cure all health problems. I have not seen nor has my wife experienced any negative side effects. We are not fearful that this can be habit-forming or addictive and its not some massive rollercoaster ride of a high then a crash like some other schedule 1 controlled substances.

The composition of this plant has made a positive change in my wifes health and in our lives. If more research is needed for FDA approval, then take the time and verify. Please, dont make this illegal just because we are not sure what positive or negative, if any, effects it has on people.   

Thank you.

Sincerely,

John Hamilton, Jr.

"Docket No.DEA-442W"
I am writing today to take part in the lawful public comment period that is finally available to us in regards to the DEA's proposed Scheduling of the herbal supplement called Kratom. As you may be aware by now the kratom community strongly objects to the DEA's scheduling of kratom as a drug. I, personally believe I have the right to kratom. And I believe that the manner in which the DEA has presented the proposed ban & scheduling of kratom to be unlawful and should therefore be completely & immediately dissolved. 
	My name is Melissa McCormick, I am a 32 year-old female from NC. I am a responsible Kratom consumer who takes kratom to improve my health and well-being. As an American citizen I believe that I have the right to have kratom & I am urging you not to schedule kratom as a drug. Kratom is not a drug; it is an Herb, a plant, not a synthetic drug, and this plant is most closely related to the coffee-family. 
	North Carolina made kratom legal as of 2016 (via State Bill 830). Many other states have recently passed similar legislation. We see this plant as a beneficial supplement. To compare a coffee plant relative to the likes of morphine, LSD, Methamphetamine's & Oxycontin is a travesty. For such a beneficial, yet harmless, plant this action of scheduling seems extreme and unjustified.
	For the millions of Americans, like myself, who do not have health insurance, but are exempt from carrying it because of financial hardships, we value botanicals & herbs!  If the DEA/FDA makes this herb unavailable to citizens like myself, then we will lose our God-given right to take a plant that helps improve our health & well-being. 
	I am not a scientist or a doctor, nor do I claim that kratom cures, treats or prevents any disease; all I know is how kratom has transformed my individual health & well-being. I am now an active, productive member of society and I wouldn't be if I had never heard of kratom.  
	My story goes like this: I was involved in a terrible car accident a few years ago. My normal life was halted all because a negligent person, using a cell phone, rear-ended my vehicle @ 55mph while I sat at a stop waiting to make a turn. The impact caused me to suffer severe head/mouth trauma. From that day on I had daily cluster migraines. The doctor had no real answers. My doctor just wanted to prescribe me powerful 'Oxycontin' pain killers. You see, I am a candidate for addiction because it runs in my family. My Father and Grandfather both battled this disease when I was a youth. My Father's long battle with addiction ended in suicide in September 2000. My doctor knew this because he was also my Father's doctor for many years and this information was also in my medical file. 
	Even so, my doctor just offered me an RX of 'Oxycontin' and went on with his day, leaving me in disarray. I knew I didn't need to let this doctor 'experiment' with my future. He had no answers, scheduled no further tests, only offered me heavy opiates and sent me away. So I refused the Oxycontin & I went home in agony & I suffered every day; in a dark room, in bed, because I couldn't stand light or sound. 
	For nearly a year, I suffered in silence. Unable to work, drive or even shower on my own- I couldn't live a normal life because I couldn't function. The accident happened in my mid-twenties, when I should have been focusing on my career or starting a family. Instead I was forced into solitude, scared, and in nearly constant agony. Then I heard about kratom.
	I learned of kratom through a small, knowledgeable online community for people with cluster migraines. I am so blessed to have found this herb/plant. After taking kratom my health & well-being improved greatly. I distinctly remember the moment when I realized that I hadn't experienced a cluster migraine in nearly 24 hours and it was a life changing moment. 
	Since then I can function, work, play and even consider having children. I can now do what most people take for granted. I have a normal life- and there is no greater treasure. 
	What does the DEA/FDA want people like me to do if they label the kratom plant as a 'drug' that must be prescribed? I will lose access to a plant/herb that has drastically improved my health & well-being for the better.  You cannot prescribe an herb to someone who cannot afford to pay for the doctor's visit in order to get the prescription! Making kratom a Schedule 1 drug will change millions of American lives for the worst- and I am included in that list.
At this point in time the Kratom community stands united in the fact that we strongly object to the DEA's proposed scheduling of Kratom and we will not be satisfied until the scheduling of kratom is null and void. 
Please intensely consider all of the information and relevant comments presented to you by the public, scientists, medical professionals and other stakeholders who submit their data and other relevant information on kratom. Thank you,  Melissa McCormick

documents.commentText:
As a citizen of the United States of America, a resident of Florida, and a physical therapy student, I hereby formally state that I am in opposition to an emergency ban on Mitragyna speciosa, also known as kratom.  

Living in Florida I have seen firsthand the damage that has been caused by prescription opioids; it has affected me personally as many of my family members, friends, and coworkers are all battling prescription opioid addictions, and some have even lost that battle along with their lives.  I also have personal experience with hydrocodone as I was prescribed it following a surgery for a fractured tibia and fibula.  The side effects I experienced included nausea, vomiting, dizziness, euphoria, impaired cognition, constipation, and sweating to list a few.  

Having personally tried kratom tea from a local kava bar this past February at the age of 21, I can say that I did not experience any of said side effects, and while I was expecting some recreational effects, I was highly disappointed.  I personally did not notice any significant effects except perhaps some mild stimulation and a slight mood boost, similar to that of coffee (those effects may have even been placebo).  I could not believe that the same herb that was infused in my tea that night has been compared to the prescription opioids that have destroyed so many lives.  I also know a number of people who take kratom regularly and I have not seen any evidence that it is negatively impacting their lives the way potent opioid medications have affected many others.

Although I did not personally experience any side effects from kratom, many have reported some side effects.  But there are many natural supplements that are effectively regulated and sold in large retail stores that also have the potential to produce side effects and even adverse effects, many of which may be dangerous under certain circumstances.  However the harm caused by these supllements is kept to a minimum through proper regulation, labeling, education, and the advice of medical professionals.  I believe kratom can effectively be regulated in the same way, especially given that there has been only one death from kratom in which other substances did not seem to be involved, and the number of poison control calls is extremely low on a relative scale.  Many other regulated products such as energy drinks have caused more harm to society than kratom[1], yet they remain legal and are instead regulated and must be properly labelled as a harm-reduction measure.  I have not seen remotely sufficient evidence reported by the DEA that suggests kratom should be treated any differently.

Aside from my personal experience, I have great concerns that the repercussions of an emergency ban will be detrimental to our society as a whole.  As it has widely been reported, scientists researching the herb to potentially discover safer and less addictive opioid pain medication alternatives will have to halt their work at a time when we need it most.  Many people may also continue to use and distribute the herb, as I believe that the majority of the informed public is against a ban and will not comply with its enforcement because they see it as unjust.  Therefore a ban may increase our rapidly growing prison population.  It may also create a black market in which adulterated and unsafe products could proliferate, and far more dangerous and addictive illegal drugs could even be sold as kratom to those that might not otherwise use illegal drugs but are familiar with kratom.

As members of congress stated in the Pocan-Salmon letter, the right to emergency ban a substance was granted in order to prevent immediate harm from dangerous synthetic substances, many of which have no existing scientific data or history of human use, and are potent enough to kill multiple people in sub-milligram dosages.  I respect and fully support the DEA's efforts in controlling such synthetic substances.  But the leaves of the kratom tree are completely different.  There is a long history of traditional use in Oceanic countries such as Indonesia, and there are growing bodies of peer-reviewed research on kratom.[2]

I believe that public and congressional sentiment, as well as the opinion scientific community, indicates that kratom does not pose an imminent hazard to public health, and therefore an emergency ban is inappropriate and is also a gross abuse of power.  While I understand and respect that the DEA acts in the best interest of public health,  I do not support its intent to place an emergency ban on kratom, and I believe that such an action will do far more harm than good.  Please reconsider your intent to place an emergency ban on this herb.

References:

1. https://cspinet.org/news/documents-link-more-deaths-energy-drinks-20140625

2. https://www.botanical-education.org/research/

My name is Dustin Dyer, I'm 32 years old and I'm the Director of Email Marketing for a dietary supplement company.

I was quite shocked when I first read that Kratom was going to be banned and labeled as a schedule 1 drug. I couldn't possibly disagree more with the DEA's decision to do this. In all of my experience, I have only benefited from the use of Kratom and I am certain that banning Kratom would be a huge mistake.

I discovered Kratom about 1 year ago when I was searching for something that could help with my chronic back pain after my chiropractor, physical therapist, & family doctor couldn't do anything to help me. After reading information on a few different websites like reddit.com/r/kratom that essentially laid everything out, I was able to read and learn until I was more comfortable with how to take it and where to purchase it.

I for one am someone that has benefited greatly from the daily use of Kratom.  I live a very active lifestyle outside of my marketing job (where I spend most of my time sitting at a desk).  So health & fitness is very important to me. Feeling less pain & anxiety has allowed me to achieve more of my fitness goals & I attribute a lot of it to Kratom.

My back pain even affected me throughout the night, so sleeping was becoming more of an issue for me. Taking Kratom before bed has helped drastically. Where I was sleeping 4-6 hours each night, I'm now able to get 7-8 and feel much better every day.

After reading a few people's concerns about Kratom's "addictive" properties, I completely quit taking it for about a week after about 6 months of daily use. The only difference I felt was that all of my issues starting coming back; difficulty sleeping, more back pain, etc. I have had surgeries in past years and have been prescribed opiates for pain, so I'm very familiar what it feels like to suddenly stop taking opiates. Kratom had none of those effects that opiates have. This is what makes this plant special.

I think that if there should be any change to the status of Kratom, it isn't that it should be scheduled as an illegal drug, but rather treated in the same light as any dietary supplement you take. It needs to be regulated so that consumers know that they're getting a quality item with a safety backing. Just like with any dietary supplement, I want to know the exact amount of the product I'm taking.

I am not one that would revert to heroin or pain killers as a replacement (although, many people would) if Kratom was made illegal, but I am sure that I would slip back into a life that I was starting to dislike and I'm afraid that I wouldn't be the man that I am now.

documents.commentText: I am 30 years old; I am married and mother to two young children. Last year, I nearly died. My doctors never figured out for sure what was going on, although most likely I have Chron's disease. Every time I ate, I would quickly suffer debilitating pain. I ate as much as I could, but I began losing weight. My doctors did tests, looked as much as they could within the confines of my insurance coverage, and tried to treat my symptoms. They were entirely unsuccessful. Eventually, I lost so much weight (roughly 25% of my body mass in three months) that my immune system began to shut down. I was getting infection after infection and antibiotics were ineffective in treating them, because antibiotics work WITH your immune system, and mine was wiped out because I couldn't eat. My doctors and I agreed that opioid pain medications were the wrong way to treat my pain; they may be effective for a time, but in the long run they tend to worsen pain associated with inflammatory bowel problems. Nevertheless, I needed pain management sufficient to at least stop the weight loss so that my immune system could recuperate. That's where kratom enters my story -- it's non addictive. It doesn't cause narcotic gut. It doesn't suppress respiration the way that opioids do, so while a person can take too much and cause themselves some discomfort, the overdose isn't dangerous. They don't die. Kratom made it possible for me to eat modest amounts of food until my symptoms disappeared. It did not make my pain disappear, but it managed it. I could eat. I could take care of my children. I could shower. I got some small measure of comfort and dignity back, and it allowed me to be functional again. I took it regularly for a few months until my body healed, and then I stopped. When I stopped, I didn't have to wean myself off of it; I just didn't take it anymore. I didn't have withdrawal. Kratom saved my life, and it let me manage my pain without danger of overdose or addiction. During the course of my illness, I sought support where I could and I met countless people who rely on kratom. It helped them with anxiety, with depression, and with pain. It allowed some of them to stop taking dangerous opioid medications -- the same ones that cause thousands of deaths in America every year. Numerous universities and scientific journals have begun studying kratom, and found it to be incredibly promising. Taking kratom away from people won't save lives, it will cost them. If the government wants to impose some regulations so that people can know just what they are buying when we buy kratom, I think you would find little opposition to that idea. Knowing we're buying kratom instead of grass cuttings would be great. But equating it to heroin because someone might sell us grass cuttings instead of our life-saving medication is NOT a reasonable response to that concern. Please don't take away my access to kratom. I'm symptom free right now; I can eat. But my other episodes came on without warning, and I don't have a way to safely protect myself without this. My kids need their mom. Their mom needs kratom.

documents.commentText:
It is time for science to be the controlling factor in the scheduling of materials. In brief:

* Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.

* If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.

* Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.

* Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down. This would be the same travesty as putting marijuana on Schedule 1. Both substances have demonstrated, effective medical uses, so it is clearly wrong to put either material on Schedule 1: no known medicinal use.

* Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.

* Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

The War on Drugs has been a massive failure and a complete waste of money. It is a 30+ year action that has imprisoned thousands of people for what is essentially a thought crime. Think alcohol's okay? Fine. Think marijuana or kratom is okay,? Go directly to jail. This makes no sense, especially since vastly more people are killed or otherwise harmed by alcohol than by either marijuana or kratom, both of which are substances that have been used by indigenous peoples for millennia.

documents.commentText:
According to the NIH[1], roughly 2 million Americans suffer from opioid addiction, a crisis tearing lives and families apart.  Most of this abuse involves legal drugs prescribed for pain relief.  We need pain relief alternatives without all the addictive and detrimental effects of opiates.  Fortunately, two of these exist and are in widespread use: cannabis and kratom.  Both of these herbal remedies have been shown to bring effective and non-addictive pain relief with substantially fewer detrimental effects than legal opiates.  Cannabis has historically been strictly controlled, but more than half of the states (after this election) have seen the wisdom of legalizing it for medical use.  Kratom should also be considered in this light; not in an outdated prohibitionist vaccuum, but in context as an important harm-reducing medical tool.  Banning Kratom would take away that tool, perversely working against the DEA's goals by increasing the prevalence of drug addiction.

[1] https://www.drugabuse.gov/about-nida/legislative-activities/testimony-to-congress/2016/americas-addiction-to-opioids-heroin-prescription-drug-abuse

documents.commentText:
I am writing to express my strong objection to the DEAs proposed plan to assign mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine as Schedule 1 substances.  It is greatly concerning that what would appear to be a hasty decision is apparently based on a paucity of data coming from a small number of poison control reports (relative to the high number of cases reported) for which confounding sources of variability (particularly, concomitant use of other substances) render it meaningless for making causal attributions between these compounds found in kratom and adverse events.  Given such lack of scientific merit or basis upon which such a proposed extreme action is being based as well as a much larger preponderance of evidence that suggests the therapeutic potential that these compounds have for an array of medical and behavioral problems, it is astonishing and concerning that the DEA is even considering assigning a Schedule 1 classification on them and thus making it impossible for research and development to be conducted on these two compounds  as well as all the other alkaloids found in kratom.  This becomes more ironic, given that the U.S. has by far the highest per capita rate of prescribing rate for prescription opioids and correspondingly (and not surprisingly) a high rate of opioid addiction and multiple testimonies of how kratom has served as a pharmacological adjunct that has helped many opioid addicts from becoming free.  As you know, many others have also reported these compounds have helped manage a wide array of pain conditions without the use or reliance on prescription opioids.  As a clinical psychologist with over 30 years of experience as a director of VA substance abuse treatment programs, chemical dependence researcher, and academician, I am quite concerned with this proposed action by the DEA.  DEAs proposed Schedule 1 action on mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine to address a putative imminent hazard to the public safety is clearly not supported by the current data.  These kind of scientific assertions would not pass peer review for publication in a scientific journal.  And the DEA wants to make a public health decision based on this?  What seems more plausible is that there is influence and involvement from big pharma over fiduciary and not public health concerns.
The U.S. has become a laughing stock in so many ways.  We have by far, the highest per capita cost for healthcare, yet our quality of healthcare is shamefully inferior  even compared to some Third World countries. Our public policies for addressing our high rates of addiction continue to focus predominantly on criminal justice rather than supporting and promulgating evidence-based research.  And now, at the same time that the Surgeon Generals Report on Alcohol, Drugs, and Health has just been published, emphasizing prescription opioid addiction (but NO mention of mitragynine or 7-hydroxymitragynine), the DEA is pursuing the Schedule 1 classification of two compounds that have many reports and testimonials of rational use and therapeutic potential.  As a citizen, psychologist, addictions researcher, and taxpayer, I am quite irritated and dismayed by this proposed action.

I am writing to urge the DEA to not classify the primary active constituents of the kratom plant (Mitragyna speciosa), mitragynine and 7-hydroxy-mitragynine, as Schedule 1 substances, deeming them unsafe and without any medicinal value.
 
This designation could not be more contrary to the truth, which is that kratom is a safe and effective - but mild - medicine. In my experience, kratom is harmless enough that it requires no regulation.

Kratom has been used safely for millennia to address pain and other maladies. It is far safer than its over-the-counter and prescription counterparts, bearing no risk of fatal overdose and no significant side effects or interactions. Scientific research has already determined that it possesses significant medicinal value. This relative of the coffee tree also boasts some of the same constituents that make other plants, such as tea, beneficial for one's health. Furthermore, it can be a substitution for people who use true opiates that can actually be damaging to themselves and society at large.
 
With Schedule 1 status, however, scientists would face significant barriers in studying kratom, and, more importantly, the millions of Americans who use it safely and responsibly will be left with far less salubrious substances to treat chronic pain and other issues. And those who choose to continue using it would become instant felons, in danger of being stripped of their freedom, their families, and their livelihoods. I cannot imagine how possession of a plant that presents no real harm would justify putting someone in prison, destroying not just their own life and future prospects but the economic stability and wellbeing of their children and spouse as well.

Kratom has provided me with immense relief from chronic back pain, due to disc herniation, leaving me better able to enjoy time with my family and focus on work, without making me dopey or craving more. I have been using kratom sporadically for about a year (no more than once or twice a week); in no way am I addicted to it - physically or psychologically - and I can take it or leave it. But I believe it is the prudent, wise, and decent thing to do to continue allowing hardworking and law-abiding Americans such as myself access to this inexpensive and safe remedy.

Let's not go down the rabbit hole of banning natural substances because we may not truly understand them. I believe we are at a point in our society where we have learned the folly of wanton prohibition. Thank you.

documents.commentText: As someone who works in the field of substance use disorder treatment (in the writing and researching of materials), I think the decision to classify kratom as a Schedule 1 drug is short-sighted and probably harmful. There are many accounts of people using kratom to ween themselves from more harmful opioid drugs (many more accounts than there are of people suffering serious harm from using it). Currently the most effective treatments for opioid use disorders are opioid substitution treatment using methadone or buprenorphine, and this are positive treatment because the reduce the harm associated with illicit drug use yet at the same time both of those drug are dangerous and addictive in their own right, and while kratom may cause dependence and may cause some harm all laboratory research to date (e.g., Vradi et al., 2016) indicates that it is a less addictive and less harmful drug than opioids. This same research indicates that kratom alkaloids may provide a safer alternative to opioids for treating serious pain. All of which suggests that kratom is not a drug without medical use, nor does it have as high a potential for abuse as do many drugs that are schedule 2, 3, or 4. While I can certainly see the value in regulating kratom, especially kratom extracts that have greater potency than the plant itself, I can see no logic in your decision to make it a schedule 1 drug. Doing so will only benefit drug companies invested in opioid medications and likely result in increased use of more dangerous opioids. I believe kratom deserves a period of serious research on it benefits and potential harms and not a rush to ban it. By all means find another mechanism to regulate it's use (e.g., through legislation) but do not take this drastic step.

They also claimed they saw an increase in shipments coming through the borders which they attributed to an "increasing epidemic". 
 
 "from January 2010 through December 2015. During the stated timeframe, U.S. poison centers received 660 calls related to kratom exposure. Of the calls reported, 487 (73.8%) reported intentional exposure to kratom, and 595 (90.2%) reported ingestion of the drug"

documents.commentText:
This is an edited clarification of ID: DEA-2016-0015-4671

I am a 60-year-old wife, mother, and grandmother and until January of 2005, I was a computer professional that managed the tech support department for a medical education company. That was when I was diagnosed with bilateral Neurogenic Thoracic Outlet Syndrome (TOS) and was faced with the prospect of multiple, highly invasive and very risky surgeries that "might" restore up to 60% of the use of my hands and arms or at 48 years old, I could choose to end my career, accept my disability, and learn how to adapt and pace myself in an effort to slow the progression of this chronic condition. I received expert opinions from specialists that I was not a good candidate for the rib resection surgeries that have helped some patients who are stricken with TOS and diagnosed early. So I made the difficult decision to stop working and to try to regain what health I could by learning how to manage the pain and progression with physical therapy and other physical modalities, narcotic pain meds, antispasmodic meds and muscle relaxers. 

When my pain management doctor fell gravely ill several years later and had to close his practice, I had to start all over again seeing various doctors, get my diagnosis reconfirmed and then find a pain management clinic willing to accept me. Despite having a huge binder with all my records and years of successful compliance, I was now eyed with suspicion that I might just be a drug seeker, which is even more demoralizing. 

I want to be very clear. I have always been a compliant patient. I have never lost a prescription. I have never requested an increase in dosage. In fact, I voluntarily decreased my dosage (with my doctor's approval) to see how well I would do on less. My medications (even my vitamins and nutritional supplements) are locked in a safe bolted to a shelf. I am NOT psychologically addicted to my pain meds. I NEVER crave these medications. I DO NOT feel or seek a HIGH and I am never pain free. And I am not a unicorn (there are more like me). Even at low doses, my body has grown physically dependent on the pain meds and I do experience severe physical withdrawal symptoms if a dose is missed.

This brings me to how I was introduced to Kratom. I am a relatively new Kratom user. I'd been researching it for a couple of months when a billing problem with the mail order pharmacy my insurance requires that I use canceled my prescription and mailed it back to me, citing that they are not allowed to hold a perfectly valid prescription while the billing department worked out the issue (my bank showed my bill had been paid electronically but it wasn't showing up on the pharmacy end). I was on the phone with the pharmacy every day three days in a row and even paid the bill a second time with a credit card. The prescription was canceled anyway and it was mailed back to me the day before the billing issue was finally cleared up on the pharmacy end. So I had to wait for the prescription to be returned in the mail before I could take it to my pain management clinic. They mailed a new prescription to the pharmacy the next day but since I only had a week left of my prescription, I had to cut my usual dosage in half hoping that it would last. This caused my body to begin withdrawal symptoms. Kratom really helped me manage the nausea, diarrhea, increased pain, and insomnia of withdrawals. Even though I paid extra to have the shipping expedited, I ran out of my pain medication while my new prescription was still being processed. I went 2 weeks at half dosage and 3 days at no dosage of my regular medication at all (then I had to titrate back up for another week). 

I can envision a day where I would seriously consider getting off the narcotic medications all together if Kratom were to continue to be available. If it were not for Kratom, I know without a doubt that the last few weeks would have been a living hell of pain and illness for me. It is easy for me to believe that this is a very viable choice for those unfortunate people who are addicted and trying to get off opiates. If you take this natural plant choice away from them, where to do they have to turn? I'm not saying that some minimal labeling and safety measures aren't in order for Kratom, just like any nutritional supplement or tea that I can purchase at the store. Please DO NOT follow through with the DEA's Intent to Schedule the alkaloids Mitragynine and 7-Hydroxymitragynine, which would make Kratom, a Schedule 1 controlled substance with no medicinal value. This would put Kratom on the same level as illegal drugs like heroin. It is a natural nutritional supplement helping many people who are suffering from chronic conditions and is also safely easing the nation's opiate epidemic problem. Scheduling it would also prevent further research which, to date, has shown that Kratom (Mitragynaspeciosa) does not cause respiratory depression; the main cause of death from opiate overdose.

I do not believe kratom should be scheduled alongside such horribly addicting drugs as heroin as it simply is nothing like heroin, is not addictive and it is a natural dietary supplement, not a synthetic substance - in fact, a close friend of mine was able to help her adult child recover from heroin addiction using only kratom to lessen the withdrawal symptoms and then following that to lessen the cravings for heroin, and kratom was easy to stop after this process as it in itself is not addictive and does not cause any significant withdrawal symptoms. It also does not carry the often fatal side effect of respiratory depression making it much safer overall. The adult child is now a productive member of society again, working and raising their own children and I do not believe this benefit should be ignored at a time when heroin abuse is at an alarming epidemic rate within our country. Kratom is merely leaf material from a tree native to  Southeast Asia and it has been used for thousands of years without incident (the only problems attached to kratom involved polypharmacy or the use of other substances at the same time, such as benzodiazepines or narcotics, both of which should never be mixed with anything else without consulting the prescribing physician, or illicit substances and/or alcohol, again neither of which should ever be mixed). Banning any of those substances will not magically cause polysubstance abuse to cease, the users will simply find other substances to abuse in their place, historically much more harmful substances as evidenced by the current rise of heroin and the illegally manufactured form of fentanyl in the face of prescription opiate medications being revoked by physicians, the latter of which were at least safe FDA-approved medications over dangerous street drugs. Addiction is not a substance issue, it is a person issue and until people address what it is inside of them that causes them to seek out escape and form addictive behaviors, whether that is a mental health issue, self-medicating a pain issue or post-traumatic stress due to prior traumas, this epidemic will rage on no matter how many substances are banned.

At a time when pain management doctors are cutting back on prescription medications for pain, kratom and other natural supplements like are more necessary than ever to give people safe alternatives. Scheduling kratom would also halt research that is necessary and should be allowed to continue.  Please keep kratom legal and available for all free citizens of America.
